and all cessations due to discrimination are called the fruits of this [path], therefore they are called the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Those attained through the power of the pure path can be established with this name.
Those attained through the power of the worldly path, such as the fruits of once-returner and non-returner,
why are they called the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a?
Answer: As the pure path abandons the defilements of the desire realm, whether by a multiple or the whole, it establishes the limit of the fruit.
In this way, the noble ones, through the worldly path, abandon the defilements of the desire realm,
whether by a multiple or the whole, also establish the fruits of once-returner and non-returner.
Therefore, the two are also called the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
The Venerable Saá¹ƒghabhadra said:
When abandoning the defilements of the desire realm through the worldly path, one also cultivates the future
pure paths. The two fruits attained are the fruits of those [paths].
They are also established with the name of the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
He should not say this.
Why is this?
Because the future noble path has no function yet.
How can one obtain the name of fruit in this and that?
Other masters say:
When one is free from the passion of desire by means of the worldly path, the attainment of the uncontaminated path always continues.
The two fruits that are obtained are the fruits of that [path].
They can also be established as the name of the fruit of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
They should not say this.
Why is this?
The attainment of the uncontaminated path has the function of realizing the severance of bonds.
How can one obtain the name of fruit in this and that?
There are also those who say:
Those who obtain the two fruits by means of the worldly path,
when the diamond-like samÄdhi is present,
generally realize the one flavor of the severance of the bonds of the seen and cultivated [afflictions] of the three realms.
Because the previously obtained severance is the fruit of that [path], it is called the fruit of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Because this samÄdhi is truly the nature of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
They also should not say this.
Why is this?
When one obtains the two fruits, one has not yet attained this samÄdhi.
If one obtains this samÄdhi, one loses the name of the fruit.
How are the two called the fruits of Å›ramaá¹‡as?
It should be said:
The name is established from the majority, because it is mostly the fruit obtained by the noble path.
That is to say, when the worldly path obtains two fruits,
the abandonment of all that is to be seen and abandoned in the three realms,
is all obtained by the power of the noble path, and is therefore called the fruit of Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Although there is the abandonment of the six or nine categories of that which is to be abandoned through cultivation in the desire realm that is not obtained by the noble path,
nevertheless, it is also established as the name of the fruit of Å›ramaá¹‡a from the majority, because it is all that is obtained by a single uncontaminated attainment.
Question: As for the four fruits of Å›ramaá¹‡as that have been explained in this way, how many are nominal and how many are real?
Answer: Two are nominal,
namely the fruit of once-returning and the fruit of non-returning.
Two are real,
namely the fruit of stream-entry and the fruit of arhatship.
Question: Why are the fruits of once-returning and non-returning called nominal fruits,
and the fruits of stream-entry and arhatship called real fruits?
Answer: The various worldly paths are nominally called paths.
The two intermediate fruits are less than what they attain.
Following the majority, they are called nominally attained fruits.
The various pure paths are truly called paths.
The first and last two fruits are completely attained by them.
Therefore, the first and last fruits are called truly attained fruits.
Furthermore, the two intermediate fruits are attained by both the worldly and pure paths, and are called nominally attained fruits.
The nominal is the meaning of being attained together.
It is like those who have in common being called nominally existent things.
The first and last two fruits are only attained by the power of the pure path, and are called truly attained fruits.
The true meaning is the meaning of being attained alone.
It is like those who have alone being called truly existent things.
Furthermore, the two intermediate fruits are attained by setting up names and words with the worldly noble path.
They are called nominally attained fruits.
That is to say, when those two paths are in the future, they provisionally make statements of meaning.
Having the same matter, they vow to do the same thing, and one should rejoice in it.
The first and last fruits are only attained by the noble path.
Because they are not attained by means of the two paths, which are designated by names.
They are called the fruits of real meaning.
Other masters say:
The nominally designated fruits
are the first two fruits, because they are only attained by the Å›rÄvaka vehicle.
The fruits of real meaning
are the last two fruits, because they are all attained by Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and great sages.
Most are of real meaning, few are nominally designated.
The judges say:
They should not say this.
Because few or many do not indicate the meaning of nominal or real.
The former explanation in this text is correct.
Why is this?
The fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a
are attained through the power of the nature of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Only the pure path is the nature of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
One who accomplishes it is called a true Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Therefore, the two fruits attained by them are called the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a of real meaning.
The worldly paths are not the nature of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
One who accomplishes them is called a nominally designated Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Therefore, the two fruits they attain are nominally called the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Question: The path is conditioned and has lower, middle, and upper levels, arising through the power of causes, and can be called a fruit.
Cessation is unconditioned and has no lower, middle, or upper levels, and is not produced by causes. How can it be called a fruit?
Answer: Although cessation is not produced, it is what is attained and realized through practice, and is therefore also called a fruit.
That is to say, a yoga practitioner dwells on a high mountain peak or in a quiet room.
They regulate their diet and reduce sleep and other necessities for the body.
They observe the small and large seven-day precepts, and practice the methods of stabilizing the crown and the vajra staff.
From the time of sunset until sunrise the next day,
They arouse supreme, vigorous, and energetic effort.
This gradually gives rise to the uncontaminated noble path.
Through this, they attain the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
At that time, the guide praises and comforts them, saying:
Excellent, excellent!

You are now able to attain this fruit through diligently cultivating right practice, just as a farmer who cultivates fields, removes weeds, and harvests crops for six months later collects the seeds and stores them in a granary.
The old farmers praise and comfort him, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
You have toiled much for six months and now you have attained this fruit.
Therefore, the path and the abandonment are both called the fruits.
These four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are explained like this.
Question: How many are fruits of dhyÄna?
Answer: Four are fruits of dhyÄna and its retinue.
Question: How many are fruits of the formless [absorptions]?
Answer: One,
namely the fruit of arhatship.
Question: How many are fruits of the fundamental dhyÄnas?
Answer: Two,
namely the fruit of non-returner and the fruit of arhatship.
Question: How many are fruits of the dhyÄna access concentrations?
Answer: Four, namely the access concentration to the first dhyÄna, not the other dhyÄnas.
The intermediate [dhyÄna] is explained like the fundamental [dhyÄna].
Question: How many are fruits of the fundamental formless [absorptions]?
Answer: One.
Namely, the fruit of arhatship.
Question: How many are the fruits of the formless preliminary stages?
Answer: None.
Question: How many are the fruits of the path of seeing?
Answer: Three.
Namely, excluding the fruit of arhatship.
Question: How many are the fruits of the path of cultivation?
Answer: Three.
Namely, excluding the fruit of stream-entry.
Question: How many are the fruits of patience?
Answer: Three.
Namely, excluding the fruit of arhatship.
Question: How many are the fruits of knowledge?
Answer: Three. Namely, excluding the fruit of stream-entry.
Question: How many are the fruits of the knowledge of dharmas?
Answer: Three.
Namely, excluding the fruit of stream-entry.
Question: How many are the fruits of the knowledge of species?
Answer: One.
Namely, the fruit of arhatship. Question: How many are the fruits of the class of the knowledge of dharmas?
Answer: Three.
Namely, excluding the fruit of stream-entry.
Question: How many are the fruits of the class of the knowledge of species?
Answer: Four.
Question: How many are the fruits of the worldly path?
Answer: Two.
Namely, the fruit of once-returning and the fruit of non-returning.
Question: How many are the fruits of the uncontaminated path?
Answer: Four.
As stated in the sutra:
The son of the king of Magadha, Ajatashatru,
came to where the Buddha was. Having arrived, he bowed at the Buddha's feet and sat to one side. He then said to the Buddha:
Is there one who presently sees the fruit of the Å›ramaá¹‡a?
The Buddha said: There is.
The king asked: What is it?
The World-Honored One said:
I will now ask the king,
and you may answer as you wish.
If the king's attendants or servants are not free,
sometimes they see the king ascend a high pavilion, set up the five kinds of music, and joyfully play with his relatives.
Having seen this, they think:
'I am also a human being. Why is it not so for me?'
However, the king in his past lives cultivated much merit and virtue.
Therefore, in this present life, he receives this supreme reward.
I should now cultivate superior karma and also be admired by the multitude like the king.'
Having thought this, he then abandons the practices of a householder,
shaves his beard and hair, and dons the dyed robes.
Upholding the Three Refuges and pure precepts.
In the ten wholesome paths, one is able to cut off and cultivate.
The king's other messengers saw this outside.
They immediately returned and reported in detail the above matter.
Requesting the king to pursue and take him back, as before, to drive and control him.
When the king heard their words, did he do as they requested?
The king said, No.
If there are such people, I should go to see them, pay homage, and make offerings.
As they previously served me,
I will now serve them for the rest of my life.
I will give them clothing, food and drink, medicine, dwellings, bedding,
And all necessary provisions, ensuring they lack nothing.
The Buddha said to the king:
Are these things not the present-day fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a?
The king said to the Buddha:
It is truly as the Sage teaches.
Question: The fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a indeed only have four.

Answer: The true fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a indeed only have four.
This refers to those who are presently seen as having attained the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
This is merely the fruit of the skillful means of those who have left the home-life.

how can it be said that they have the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a?
Answer: Although those who have left the home-life are not of the true nature of Å›ramaá¹‡as,

they say, I see such a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Therefore, the fruit of the skillful means of those who have left the home-life
can also be provisionally established as the fruit of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
This term presently seen indicates that it is not a true meaning.

namely the first kind of Å›ramaá¹‡a up to the fourth kind.
In the Dharma of non-Buddhists there are no true Å›ramaá¹‡as or brÄhmaá¹‡as.
There are only empty titles.
In such matters, in the midst of the great assembly, one can roar the lion's roar without any fear.
One should know that among them, the first kind of Å›ramaá¹‡a refers to those who have entered the stream.
The second Å›ramaá¹‡a is the once-returner.
The third Å›ramaá¹‡a is the non-returner.
The fourth Å›ramaá¹‡a is the arhat.
Venerable PÄrÅ›va said:
One should know that here the Buddha, following the superior ones, first spoke of the arhats as the first Å›ramaá¹‡a.
The second Å›ramaá¹‡a is the non-returner.
The third Å›ramaá¹‡a is the once-returner.
The fourth Å›ramaá¹‡a is the stream-enterer. The SÅ«tra of Subhadra also says:
If there is the eightfold noble path here, one should know that there are four Å›ramaá¹‡as here,
namely the first Å›ramaá¹‡a up to the fourth.
Here, some say:
The paths leading to the four fruits are called the four Å›ramaá¹‡as.
The first Å›ramaá¹‡a is the path leading to the fruit of stream-entry.
The second Å›ramaá¹‡a is the path leading to the fruit of once-returning.
The third Å›ramaá¹‡a is the path leading to the fruit of non-returning.
The fourth Å›ramaá¹‡a is the path leading to the fruit of arhatship.
Venerable PÄrÅ›va said:
This sutra speaks of four kinds of those who are progressing towards [the fruits] and four fruits.
If there are eight branches of the noble path in a place, then four kinds of those who are progressing towards [the fruits] are spoken of.
One should know that in a place where there are four kinds of Å›ramaá¹‡as, then four fruits are spoken of.
The Cunda SÅ«tra also says:
There are four kinds of Å›ramaá¹‡as, there is no fifth.
The four kinds of Å›ramaá¹‡as are:
1. The supreme path Å›ramaá¹‡a.
2. The path-showing Å›ramaá¹‡a.
3. The path-life Å›ramaá¹‡a.

One should know that among them, the supreme path Å›ramaá¹‡a is:
The World-Honored Buddha, because he himself has realized [the truth].
All pratyekabuddhas should be known as being the same.
The path-showing Å›ramaá¹‡a is:
The Venerable ÅšÄriputra.
Because he is unequaled.
Because he is the great Dharma heir.
Because he is always able to turn the Dharma wheel in accordance with the Buddha.
All those who have no more learning to do among the Å›rÄvakas should be known as being the same.
The path-life Å›ramaá¹‡a is:
The Venerable Ä€nanda.
Although they are in the stage of learning, they are the same as those beyond learning in being well-versed, upholding what they have heard, and possessing pure precepts.

As for the Å›ramaá¹‡a who defiles the path,
it refers to the bhiká¹£u Moheluojia who delights in stealing the property of others and so forth.
Question: What are the differences between the Å›ramaá¹‡as mentioned in the above three sÅ«tras that were quoted?
There is an explanation that:
The ÅšÄ«lapatala SÅ«tra says that Å›ramaá¹‡as are those who abide in the four fruits.

The Subhadra SÅ«tra says that Å›ramaá¹‡as are those who practice the four approaches. The CÅ«dÄpaká¹£a SÅ«tra says that Å›ramaá¹‡as are those who abide in the four fruits and practice the various approaches.
Other masters say:ğŸ”½The ÅšÄ«lapatala SÅ«tra says that Å›ramaá¹‡as are those who abide in the four fruits.

The CÅ«dÄpaká¹£a SÅ«tra says that Å›ramaá¹‡as completely encompass all Å›ramaá¹‡as.

The Lion's Roar Sutra and the Sutra of Subhadra say that Å›ramaá¹‡as are those who abide in the four fruits. The Sutra of Cunda says that Å›ramaá¹‡as are those who have attained the path.

The Lion's Roar Sutra and the Sutra of SubhÅ«ti say that Å›ramaá¹‡as refer to those abiding in the four fruits. According to the Cunda Sutra, Å›ramaá¹‡as refer to those abiding in the fruits and paths.
There are also those who say:
The Lion's Roar Sutra and the Sutra of SubhÅ«ti say that Å›ramaá¹‡as refer to those in training and those beyond training.
According to the Cunda Sutra, Å›ramaá¹‡as refer to those in training, those beyond training, and those neither in training nor beyond training.
There are those who say:
The Lion's Roar Sutra and the Sutra of SubhÅ«ti say that Å›ramaá¹‡as refer to the noble ones.

There are also those who say:
The meanings of Å›ramaá¹‡a as explained in these three sÅ«tras are no different.
Question: The first two sÅ«tras say there are four kinds of Å›ramaá¹‡as.
Are those who defile the path included in the four?
Answer: They are also included in the four.
Namely, the approach to the fruit of stream-entry.
However, the approach to the fruit of stream-entry is near or far.
Near means the path of seeing.
Far means those who have previously cultivated the factors conducive to penetration, the factors conducive to liberation, up to those who have gone forth with right faith.
As stated in the sutra:
There are four factors of the approach to the fruit of stream-entry.
Namely, associating with good people,
listening to the true Dharma,ğŸ”½proper contemplation,ğŸ”½and practicing the Dharma in accordance with the Dharma.
The factors are the causes of the approach.
The name and meaning of the approach are without distinction.
The Sutra of Subahu asks:
If there are eight branches of the noble path in a place, one should know that in that place there are four kinds of monks.
Are those who defile the path included in this?
Answer: They are also included in this.
Because the branches of the noble path are real or provisional.
Real means the eight uncontaminated ones such as right view.
Provisional means the eight contaminated ones such as right view.
Those who defile the path can also attain the contaminated right view.
Therefore, they are also included in the first type of Å›ramaá¹‡a.
There is another explanation.
The first two sÅ«tras say that the four types of Å›ramaá¹‡as are the third type.
The four types of superior paths and so forth mentioned in the sÅ«tras are not the stream-enterers and so forth.
Therefore, there is no difference in the meaning of the three sÅ«tras.
Question: How can the first sÅ«tra be explained?
Only in our Dharma are there four types of Å›ramaá¹‡as.
The Buddha roared the lion's roar correctly in the assembly.
How could the World-Honored One say that only in our Dharma
are there those who violate the precepts and roar the lion's roar?
Answer: Saying it is also not wrong.
Why is it so?
Although the Å›ramaá¹‡a who defiles the path breaks the precepts, he does not break his views.
Although he breaks the practice, he does not break his intention.
Suppose there is a question:
Is your violation of the precepts evil or not evil?
He says it is not evil.
Should it be done or should it not be done?
He says it should not be done.
Does it have retribution or does it not have retribution?
He says it has retribution.
whether it is to obtain a lovable result or an unlovable result.
They say it is to obtain an unlovable result.
Whether it is to experience the evil destinies or the good destinies.
They say it is to experience the evil destinies.
Whether it is to experience it oneself.
Or whether it is to experience it in another's body.
They say it is to experience it oneself.
Whether it is the fault of the teacher, the fault of the teaching, or one's own fault.
They say it is not the fault of the teacher.
Nor is it the fault of the teaching, it is my own fault.
They have such contaminated right view.
They believe in cause and effect.
They are not ignorant of cause and effect.
Such right view.
Is not possessed by the ninety-six kinds of non-Buddhists.
Therefore the Buddha roars the true lion's roar among the assembly.
Relying on that, it is also said without fault, as stated in the sutra.
The Buddha told the bhikshus.
I truly know and see that there are three kinds of people.
Who do much for all sentient beings, whose kindness is difficult to repay.
Even if one were to use the best clothes, food and drink, bedding and medicine to the end of one's life.
and other necessary conditions to make offerings to them.
One is still unable to repay them.
What are the three?
First, there are people who explain the Dharma for others,
encouraging them to abandon the lifestyle of a householder and enter the non-householder's life,
shaving off their hair and beard, and donning the monastic robes,
upholding the pure precepts with right faith.
Second, there are people who explain the Dharma for others,
encouraging them to know that all phenomena of accumulation are phenomena of cessation,
to distance themselves from defilements, and to give rise to the pure Dharma eye with regard to all phenomena.
Third, there are people who explain the Dharma for others,
encouraging them to exhaust all defilements, realize the undefiled liberation of mind and wisdom,
and fully abide in the present life, with the end of rebirth and so forth.
If one encourages others to receive the precepts of the lay devotee,
this person is also said to have done much that is difficult to repay.
Why is this not mentioned in the sutra?
The answer is that it should be mentioned, but it is not.
One should know that there is more to this meaning.
Furthermore, the precepts of renunciation are both the cause and the effect, so the sÅ«tra emphasizes them.
That is to say, this is the effect of the precepts of the lay practitioner.
The precepts of the fully ordained monk are the cause.
Furthermore, encouraging renunciation
is precisely encouraging people to enter the holy Dharma, so the sÅ«tra emphasizes it.
Entering the holy Dharma is roughly of two kinds.
First, the conventional.
Second, the ultimate.
The conventional means
renouncing the practices of the household and entering the non-household,
shaving the beard and hair, and wearing the monastic robe.
With right faith, upholding the pure precepts.
The ultimate means
from the supreme worldly dharmas entering the acceptance of the knowledge of the Dharma of suffering.ğŸ”½Furthermore, encouraging renunciation
is precisely encouraging people to escape from the lowly and base, so the sÅ«tra emphasizes it.
That is to say, those in the household are often oppressed by various lowly and base evil things.
The renunciant monks are liberated from this.
Furthermore, encouraging renunciation
It is precisely because it encourages people to liberate themselves from various sufferings that the sÅ«tra emphasizes this.
It means that those who have left the household life are liberated from the suffering and distress of the present body.
Because of this, they gradually liberate themselves from all birth, old age, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress, and from the phenomena of birth and death.
Furthermore, encouraging people to leave the household life
is precisely encouraging people to experience the bliss of the present Dharma.
Because of this, they gradually attain ultimate mastery and bliss. Therefore, the sÅ«tra emphasizes this.
Furthermore, encouraging people to leave the household life
is precisely encouraging people to manifest the Buddha's appearance in the world. Therefore, the sÅ«tra emphasizes this.
The manifestation of the Buddha's appearance in the world is roughly of two kinds.
First, the conventional;
second, the ultimate.
The conventional means
renouncing the household life and entering the non-household life,
shaving the beard and hair, and wearing the monastic robe,
upholding the pure precepts with right faith.
The ultimate means
attaining true and pure understanding of the Four Noble Truths.
When one first leaves the household life,
one has already manifested the conventional appearance of the Buddha in the world.
Having gone forth, they will gradually practice.
And will manifest the supreme truth, with a Buddha appearing in the world.
Next, encouraging going forth
Is precisely encouraging people to learn the Buddha's body, so the sÅ«tra emphasizes this.
The Buddha's body is roughly of two kinds.
First, the birth body.
Second, the Dharma body.
If one abandons the way of the household and enters the non-household,
Shaves the beard and hair, and wears the monastic robe,
With right faith, upholds pure precepts,
One should know that this is learning the Buddha's birth body.
If one is able to gradually cultivate right practice,
And give rise to true pure understanding of the Four Noble Truths,
One should know that this is learning the Buddha's Dharma body.
Next, encouraging going forth
Is precisely encouraging people to learn the Buddha's practices, so the sÅ«tra emphasizes this.
The Buddha's practices are roughly of two kinds.
First, the conventional.
Second, the supreme truth.
The conventional means
Abandoning the way of the household and entering the non-household.
Shaving off one's beard and hair and wearing the kÄá¹£Äya robe.
With the correct faith, upholding the pure precepts.
The ultimate truth.
It refers to being able to correctly understand the four noble truths.
When first leaving the household life, one is already able to follow and learn the worldly Buddha's practices.
Having left the household life, one diligently practices.
One is also able to follow and learn the ultimate Buddha's practices.
Furthermore, encouraging leaving the household life.
This is because it encourages people to enter the ocean of the Buddha's teachings, so the sÅ«tra speaks of it in particular.
It means that if there are people who abandon the affairs of the household and leave the household life with pure faith,
This is called first entering the ocean of the Buddha's teachings.
If one exhausts the defilements and realizes parinirvÄá¹‡a,
This is called ultimately entering the ocean of the Buddha's teachings.
Furthermore, encouraging leaving the household life.
This is because it encourages people to decisively enter the path of true liberation, so the sÅ«tra speaks of it in particular.
As the sÅ«tra says:
Those who leave the household life,
Will definitely attain the wisdom and insight of the four noble truths in reality.
Furthermore, encouraging leaving the household life.
It is exhorting people to definitely attain three kinds of precepts, namely:
The precept of individual liberation,ğŸ”½The precept of meditation,
And the precept of being free from defilements.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra emphasizes this.
Furthermore, exhorting those who have left the household life
Is exhorting people to definitely attain three kinds of wholesome aggregates, namely:
The aggregate of morality, the aggregate of concentration, and the aggregate of wisdom.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra emphasizes this.
Just as with the three wholesome aggregates, the three trainings, the three cultivations, and the three purities should be understood in the same way.
Furthermore, exhorting those who have left the household life
Is exhorting people to definitely attain three kinds of right paths, namely: the path of seeing, the path of cultivation, and the path of no-more-learning. Therefore, the sÅ«tra emphasizes this.
Just as with the three right paths, the three stages are also like this.
Furthermore, exhorting those who have left the household life

Is exhorting people to definitely attain three kinds of uncontaminated faculties, namely: the faculty of knowing the unknown, the faculty of knowing, and the faculty of having known. Therefore, the sÅ«tra emphasizes this.
Furthermore, exhorting those who have left the household life
It is exhorting people to attain the three kinds of enlightenment as appropriate.
Namely, the enlightenment of the Å›rÄvakas, the enlightenment of the pratyekabuddhas, and the supreme enlightenment.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra speaks of it in particular.
Furthermore, exhorting those who have left the household life
Is exhorting people to definitely attain the three kinds of muni.
Namely, the muni of the body, the muni of speech, and the muni of the mind. Therefore, the sÅ«tra speaks of it in particular.
The three kinds of tranquility and the three kinds of purity are also like this.
Furthermore, exhorting those who have left the household life
Is exhorting people to have physical and mental detachment. Therefore, the sÅ«tra speaks of it in particular.
When one leaves the household life, the body becomes free from many affairs.
Because the body is free from many affairs, the mind is also free from many affairs.
Because of this, one is far removed from afflictions and evil karma.
Furthermore, exhorting those who have left the household life is exhorting people to have a body and mind free from defilements. Therefore, the sÅ«tra speaks of it in particular.
When one leaves the household life, the body becomes pure.
Because the body is pure, the mind is also pure.
Because the body and mind are pure, the defilements of afflictions and karma are quickly eliminated.
Furthermore, exhorting those who have left the household life
It is precisely because it encourages people to have a wonderful and excellent body and mind that the sÅ«tra speaks of it in particular.
It means that when one goes forth from home, one's body becomes wonderful and excellent.
Because the body is wonderful and excellent, the mind is also wonderful and excellent.
Furthermore, encouraging one to go forth from home
is precisely because it encourages people to have a dignified and majestic body and mind, so the sÅ«tra speaks of it in particular.
It means that when one goes forth from home, one's body becomes dignified and majestic.
Because the body is dignified and majestic, the mind is also dignified and majestic. Furthermore, encouraging one to go forth from home
is precisely because it encourages people to definitely attain ultimate quiescence, which is nirvÄá¹‡a, so the sÅ«tra speaks of it in particular.
Furthermore, encouraging one to go forth from home
is precisely because it encourages people to attain the uncommon dharmas, so the sÅ«tra speaks of it in particular.
It means that when one goes forth from home, one's deportment, attire, and activities
are not shared by all householders.
Furthermore, encouraging one to go forth from home
is precisely because it encourages people to abandon afflictions and karma, so the sÅ«tra speaks of it in particular.
It means that when one goes forth from home, one shaves one's beard and hair, dons the dyed robes, and upholds the pure precepts.
Afflictions and evil karma are all gradually abandoned.
Because the appearance and adornments of renunciant life are not suitable for them.
It is like a fragrant and clean person who does not dwell in a foul-smelling place.
Furthermore, encouraging renunciation

is precisely encouraging people to create inexhaustible karma and obtain inexhaustible wealth.ğŸ”½To create blameless karma and obtain blameless wealth.ğŸ”½To create harmless karma and obtain harmless wealth.
To create karma not shared by non-Buddhists and obtain wealth not shared by non-Buddhists.
To create karma not shared by ordinary beings
and obtain wealth not shared by ordinary beings.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra speaks of it in a biased way.
Furthermore, encouraging renunciation
is precisely encouraging people to practice the conduct of the conch-marked one exclusively.
That is, to cultivate pure and chaste conduct for one's whole life.
Those who are householders are not able to do so.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra speaks of it in a biased way.
Question: What is the meaning of the conduct of the conch-marked one?
Venerable Vasumitra says:
In the past, there were two sages in this continent.
One was named Åšaá¹…kha and the other was named Likhita.
They were fully endowed with the first proper and chaste conduct.
All householders are unable to match this.
Encouraging people to go forth is the same as encouraging them to be like this.
Some say:
It is like the patterns carved on a conch shell, which are solid and difficult to destroy.
Even if blown by the wind, exposed to the sun, or affected by other external conditions, they are still difficult to destroy.
The practice of those who have gone forth is also like this.
Household people are unable to cultivate such practice.
Although they may temporarily uphold it, they will soon destroy it.
Other masters say:
It is like the patterns carved on a conch shell, which are clean and clear, without any impurities.
The practice of those who have gone forth is also like this.
Household people are unable to cultivate such practice.
Although they may uphold it to the utmost, it is still mixed with impurities.
It is commonly seen that householders attain the fruit of non-returner.
Although they are free from the defilements of desire, they still live in a household.
They accept and keep things that are not necessary for living beings.
The work they do is not yet very pure.
How much less could a householder attain the first two fruits, which would be no different from the ordinary people.
Although those who have left the household life may break the precepts,
they are still superior to those who remain in the household life and uphold the precepts.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra speaks of this in a biased way.
It encourages people to leave the household life, and the kindness [of those who do so] is difficult to repay.
Furthermore, encouraging people to leave the household life
is the same as encouraging people to cultivate the occupation of the noble ones.
The fruits and rewards they attain surpass those of King Yama, the wheel-turning king, and Åšakra.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra speaks of this in a biased way.
Encouraging people to leave the household life, the kindness [of those who do so] is difficult to repay.
Encouraging people to uphold the precepts of the lay followers and so forth,
there is no such [benefit], therefore the sÅ«tra does not speak of it.
Question: Why does this sÅ«tra only say that the kindness of enabling people to attain the first and last two fruits is difficult to repay,
and does not say that enabling people to attain the two intermediate fruits [is difficult to repay]?
Answer: As for what should be said but is not said,
one should know that there is a remainder to this meaning.
Furthermore, here [the sÅ«tra] completely includes the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Why is this so?
As for shaking off dust and dirt, giving rise to the pure Dharma eye with regard to dharmas, this refers to the first three fruits.
It means those who are bound by all fetters and have already separated from the five categories of defilements of the desire realm.
Entering the certainty of the Dharma, giving rise to the pure Dharma eye, and attaining the fruit of stream-entry.
If one has already separated from the sixth and seventh categories of defilements of the desire realm.
Entering the certainty of the Dharma, giving rise to the pure Dharma eye, and attaining the fruit of once-returning.
If one has already separated from the defilements up to the sphere of nothingness.
Entering the certainty of the Dharma, giving rise to the pure Dharma eye, and attaining the fruit of non-returning.
Causing the exhaustion of all defilements and attaining the undefiled.
The one who is liberated by mind and wisdom is precisely the one who attains the fruit of arhatship.
Therefore, this sÅ«tra completely includes the four fruits.
Furthermore, this sÅ«tra says that attaining the first and last two fruits is precisely attaining the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Because it shows the beginning and end.
The beginning refers to the fruit of stream-entry.
The end is precisely the fruit of arhatship.
Just as it shows the beginning and end, so should one understand the initial entry, the already crossed over, the effort, and the ultimate.

Furthermore, this scripture says that one who attains the first and last two fruits has already attained the two intermediate fruits. That is to say, one who attains the fruit of stream-entry will definitely attain the fruit of once-returning without interval.
One who attains the fruit of arhatship will definitely attain the fruit of non-returning immediately before that. Therefore,
Furthermore, the first and last two fruits are definitely attained by the power of the uncontaminated path, so they are mentioned separately.
The two intermediate fruits may be attained by the power of the conventional path, so they are not mentioned here.
Just as they are attained by the contaminated and uncontaminated paths,
It should be understood that they are also attained by the power of the paths of bondage and liberation.
Furthermore, the first and last two fruits are both attained by transcending the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception, so they are mentioned separately.
That is to say, the fruit of stream-entry transcends the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception and attains what is eliminated by seeing.
The fruit of arhatship transcends the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception and attains what is eliminated by cultivation.
Furthermore, this scripture briefly shows the first entrance,
Therefore, it only mentions the first and last two fruits.
It means that the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are obtained through the path of seeing.
Some are obtained through the path of cultivation.
If it is said that the fruit of stream-entry should be understood as generally speaking obtained through the path of seeing,
if it is said that the fruit of arhatship should be understood as generally speaking obtained through the path of cultivation,
just as it is obtained through the path of seeing and the path of cultivation,
so should it be understood that the stage of seeing, the stage of cultivation, the faculty of understanding the unknown, and the faculty of final knowledge are obtained in the same way.
Furthermore, the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are established because of the exhaustion of the defilements to be eliminated by seeing.
Some are established because of the exhaustion of the defilements to be eliminated by cultivation.
If it is said that the fruit of stream-entry should be understood as generally speaking established because of the exhaustion of the defilements to be eliminated by seeing,
if it is said that the fruit of arhatship should be understood as generally speaking established because of the exhaustion of the defilements to be eliminated by cultivation,
just as it is established because of the exhaustion of the defilements to be eliminated by seeing and cultivation,
so it is established because of the exhaustion of the defilements with and without objects.
It is established because of the exhaustion of the defilements opposed by patience and opposed by knowledge.
It should be understood in the same way.
Furthermore, the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are established.
Some are established to counteract the discursive thoughts of views.

Some are established to counteract the discursive thoughts of craving.ğŸ”½If the fruit of stream-entry is mentioned, it should be understood that it is generally established to counteract the discursive thoughts of views.
If the fruit of arhatship is mentioned, it should be understood that it is generally established to counteract the discursive thoughts of craving.
Just as it is established to counteract the two kinds of discursive thoughts,
one should understand that it is the same in this way to counteract the two extremes, the two arrows, and the two roots of dispute.
Furthermore, the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a areğŸ”½attained due to suddenly severing the afflictions.
Or they are attained due to gradually severing the afflictions.
If the fruit of stream-entry is mentioned,
it should be understood that it is generally attained due to suddenly severing the afflictions.
This refers to those who attain the fruit of once-returning or non-returning by transcending [the stages].
If the fruit of arhatship is mentioned,
it should be understood that it is generally attained due to gradually severing the afflictions.
This refers to those who attain the fruit of once-returning or non-returning in sequence.
For these and other various reasons,
this sÅ«tra only says that the kindness of causing others to attain the first and last two fruits is difficult to repay.
The learner dharmas that are accomplished by all stream-enterers,
are these dharmas included in the fruit of stream-entry?
And so on, it is explained in detail.
Why was this treatise composed?
The answer is: Previously, only the unconditioned fruits of Å›ramaá¹‡ahood were discussed.
Now, in order to discuss both the conditioned and unconditioned fruits of Å›ramaá¹‡ahood, this treatise is composed.
The questions in this [treatise] are first brief and then detailed.
That is to say, first it asks about the learner and post-learner dharmas that are accomplished,
next it asks about the pure dharmas that are accomplished,
and finally it asks about all dharmas that are accomplished.
The learner dharmas that are accomplished by all stream-enterers,
are these dharmas included in the fruit of stream-entry?
The answer is: Sometimes they are included, sometimes they are not.
Because the meaning is indefinite.
How are they included?
The answer is: The conditioned fruit of stream-entry that has been attained and not lost.
That which has been attained.
It refers to the faculties of the lineage included in the fruit of stream-entry that are attained by one of faith and direct-knowledge.
It refers to the faculties of the lineage included in the fruit of stream-entry that are attained by one of view and direct-knowledge.
As for the phrase not lost,

it means that one of faith does not change faculties to become one of view.ğŸ”½One does not lose the faculties of the lineage included in the fruit of stream-entry attained by one of faith and direct-knowledge.
Or one does not retrogress and lose them.
How is it that they are not included?
The answer is: The uncontaminated faculties, etc. that are the higher attainments of a stream-enterer are wholesome dharmas.
That is to say, [they are attained] when one is free from the first six categories of defilements abandoned by cultivation in the desire realm.
The paths of preparation, the six uninterrupted paths, the five paths of liberation, and the paths of advancement,
such wholesome dharmas are not included in the fruit of stream-entry even though a stream-enterer may possess them.
This is because the higher path is not included in the fruit.
If a dharma is included in the fruit of stream-entry, is it a wholesome dharma?
The answer is: It may be a wholesome dharma, or it may not be a wholesome dharma or an uncontaminated dharma.
The meaning is indefinite.
What is a wholesome dharma?
Answer: The conditioned pre-stream entry fruit.
Namely, the knowledge of the path and so forth, as well as their retinue.
What is neither training nor post-training?
Answer: The unconditioned pre-stream entry fruit.
Namely, the cessation of dharmas to be eliminated by seeing the three realms.
The training dharmas accomplished by those who have attained the once-returner fruit.
Are these dharmas included in the once-returner fruit?
Answer: Some are included, some are not.
Because the meaning is indefinite.
What is included?
Answer: The conditioned once-returner fruit that has been attained and not lost.
As for attained,
it refers to those of the faith-liberated type who have attained the once-returner fruit of the faith-liberated type.
It refers to those of the view-attained type who have attained the once-returner fruit of the view-attained type.
As for not lost,
it refers to those of the faith-liberated type who do not change their faculties to become view-attained, and thus do not lose the once-returner fruit of the faith-liberated type.
Or, they do not regress.
What is not included?
Answer: The advanced uncontaminated faculties and conditioned dharmas obtained by those who have attained the once-returner fruit.
It refers to being separated from the three lowest grades of defilements to be eliminated through cultivation in the desire realm.
The paths of preparation, three uninterrupted paths, two paths of liberation,
and the paths of advancement. Such learner dharmas
are accomplished by the once-returner,
but are not included in the once-returner fruit.
This is because the superior fruit path is not included in the fruit.
If a dharma is included in the once-returner fruit, is it a learner dharma?
The answer is: It may be a learner dharma, or it may be neither a learner nor post-learner dharma.
This is because the meaning is indefinite.
What is a learner dharma?
The answer is: The conditioned once-returner fruit.
That is, the path of the knowledge of the realization of the truths, etc.,
or the sixth path of liberation, etc., for one separated from the defilements of the desire realm, and their retinue.
What is neither a learner nor post-learner dharma?
The answer is: The unconditioned once-returner fruit.
That is, the elimination of the dharmas to be eliminated by seeing the three realms,
and the elimination of the first six grades of dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation in the desire realm.
The learner dharmas accomplished by the non-returners,
are these dharmas included in the non-returner fruit?
The answer is: sometimes it includes, sometimes it does not. The meaning is indefinite.
How does it include?
The answer is: the conditioned non-returner fruit that has been attained and not lost.
As for attained,
it refers to the faith-liberated one who has attained the faith-liberated non-returner fruit that includes the faculties of the spiritual lineage.
The view-attained one who has attained the view-attained non-returner fruit that includes the faculties of the spiritual lineage.
As for not lost,
it refers to the faith-liberated one who does not change faculties to become view-attained.
Therefore, the faith-liberated non-returner fruit that includes the faculties of the spiritual lineage is not lost.
Or it is not lost.
How does it not include?
The answer is: the uncontaminated faculties and other conditioned dharmas that are the superior progress attained by the non-returners.
It refers to those who are free from the defilements of the first meditative absorption up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
The paths of preparation and the uninterrupted paths,
as well as the path of liberation and the path of superior progress for the learner.
Such learner dharmas,ğŸ”½although the non-returner may accomplish them,
they are not included in the non-returner fruit.
Because the superior fruit path is not included in the fruit.
If a dharma is included in the fruit of non-returner, is it a learner dharma?
The answer is: it may be a learner, or it may be neither a learner nor post-learner.
Because the meaning is indefinite.
How is it a learner?
The answer is: conditioned non-returner fruit.
That is, the path of conformity knowledge, etc., or the ninth liberation path, etc., that is free from attachment to desire, and their retinue. How is it neither a learner nor post-learner?
The answer is: unconditioned non-returner fruit.
That is, the cessation of the views-to-be-abandoned in the three realms,
and the cessation of the cultivations-to-be-abandoned in the desire realm.
The post-learner dharmas accomplished by all arhats,
are these dharmas included in the fruit of arhatship?
The answer is: so it is.
That is, all the preparatory, uninterrupted, liberated, and enhanced paths accomplished by arhats are included in the fruit of arhatship.
Because they have no superior fruit path,
and there is no superior fruit to be sought.
If a dharma is included in the fruit of arhatship,
is it a post-learner dharma?
Answer: Either post-learner or neither learner nor post-learner.
Because the meaning is indefinite.
How is it post-learner?
Answer: The conditioned arhat fruit.
Namely, the knowledge of destruction, the knowledge of non-arising, the right view of the post-learner, and their retinue.
How is it neither learner nor post-learner?
Answer: The unconditioned arhat fruit.
Namely, the cessation of all dharmas abandoned by seeing and cultivation in the three realms.
The uncontaminated dharmas accomplished by all stream-enterers.
Are these dharmas included in the fruit of stream-entry?
Answer: Either included or not included.
Because the meaning is indefinite.
How are they included?
Answer: The conditioned and unconditioned fruits of stream-entry that have been attained and not lost.
The conditioned fruit of stream-entry.
Namely, the knowledge of the classes of the path, etc., and their retinue.
The unconditioned fruit of stream-entry.
Namely, the cessation of dharmas abandoned by seeing in the three realms.
Those who have attained.
Namely, those of faith-liberation who have attained the seeds included in the fruit of stream-entry of those of faith-liberation.
The faculties of their nature.
Those who have attained the state of seeing have already attained the seeds included in the fruit of the stream-enterer.
The nature of the faculties.
And the abandonment of the dharmas to be abandoned by seeing the three realms.
Those who have not lost [the seeds] refer to those of faith and understanding who do not change their faculties to become those of seeing.
Therefore, they do not lose the seeds included in the fruit of the stream-enterer of faith and understanding.
The nature of the faculties.
Or they do not retrogress.
How are they not included?
Answer: The uncontaminated faculties, etc., that are advanced attainments obtained by stream-enterers are conditioned dharmas.
And the exhaustion of the bonds that they realize.
And the non-analytical cessation that is accomplished by stream-enterers.
The uncontaminated faculties, etc., that are advanced attainments obtained by stream-enterers.
The conditioned dharmas.
Refer to the separation from the first six categories of defilements to be abandoned by cultivation in the desire realm.
The paths of preparation, the six uninterrupted paths, the five paths of liberation, and the paths of further progress.
Such uncontaminated dharmas.
Although stream-enterers accomplish them,ğŸ”½They are not included in the fruit of the stream-enterer.
Because the path of the superior fruit is not included in the fruit.
And the various bonds that are severed by that realization.
This refers to the severing of the five lower grades of dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation in the desire realm.
Because this is the severing realized by the path of superior fruit.
Just as the path of superior fruit
is not included in this fruit.
And the non-analytical cessation that is accomplished by the stream-enterer.
This refers to the non-analytical cessation that the stream-enterer attains regarding the three realms and the uncontaminated dharmas.
Although the stream-enterer accomplishes this non-analytical cessation,
this non-analytical cessation is not included in the fruit of stream-entry.
Why is this?
Because non-analytical cessation is indeterminate,
while the fruit of stream-entry is wholesome.
If a dharma is included in the fruit of stream-entry,
is this an uncontaminated dharma?
The answer is: It is so.
This is because the conditioned and unconditioned fruits of stream-entry are both uncontaminated.
The uncontaminated dharmas that are accomplished by the once-returner,
are these dharmas included in the fruit of once-returning?
The answer is: They may be included or not included.
The meaning is indefinite.
How are they included?
Answer: The conditioned and unconditioned once-returner fruits that have been attained and not lost.
The conditioned once-returner fruit.
Refers to the knowledge of the class of the path, etc.
Or the sixth path of liberation, etc. for the separation from the passion of desire, and their retinue.
The unconditioned once-returner fruit.
Refers to the cessation of the dharmas to be eliminated by seeing the three realms.
And the cessation of the dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation in the first six categories of the desire realm.
Those that have been attained.
Refers to the faith-liberated one who has attained the seeds included in the once-returner fruit of the faith-liberated type.
The various faculties.
The view-attained one who has attained the seeds included in the once-returner fruit of the view-attained type.
The various faculties.
And the cessation of the dharmas to be eliminated by seeing the three realms.
And the cessation of the dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation in the first six categories of the desire realm.
Those that are not lost.
Refers to the faith-liberated one who does not change faculties to become view-attained.
Therefore, the seeds included in the once-returner fruit of the faith-liberated type.
The various faculties.
Or the non-retrogression from this and the cessation of the dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation in the first six categories of the desire realm.
How is it not included?
Answer: The superior uncontaminated faculties, etc., and conditioned dharmas obtained by the once-returner,
and the abandonment of all bonds realized by him,
and the non-analytical cessation accomplished by the once-returner,
The superior uncontaminated faculties, etc., and conditioned dharmas obtained by the once-returner refer to
the abandonment of the last three categories of defilements to be eliminated by cultivation in the desire realm.
The paths of preparation, three uninterrupted paths, two paths of liberation, and the paths of further progress,
such uncontaminated dharmas,
although accomplished by the once-returner,
are not included in the fruit of the once-returner.
This is because the path of superior fruit is not included in the fruit.
And the abandonment of all bonds realized by him refers to
the elimination of the seventh and eighth categories of dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation in the desire realm.
This is because the elimination realized by the path of superior fruit is
like the path of superior fruit, not included in this fruit.
And the non-analytical cessation accomplished by the once-returner refers to
That is to say, a once-returner attains non-analytical cessation with regard to the three realms and the uncontaminated dharmas.
Although they accomplish this non-analytical cessation,
this non-analytical cessation is not included in the fruit of once-returning.
Why is this?
Non-analytical cessation is indeterminate,ğŸ”½while the fruit of once-returning is wholesome.
If a dharma is included in the fruit of once-returning,
is it an uncontaminated dharma?
Answer: It is so.
That is to say, the conditioned and unconditioned fruits of once-returningğŸ”½are both uncontaminated.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
